Award.AwardTitle: Nuclear Properties and Interactions from Lattice QCD
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nuclei are among the most complex systems that emerge from Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the fundamental theory of the strong interaction, and it is of great importance to understand their emergence quantitatively. This goal is only now beginning to be realized in practice using Lattice QCD and effective field theory methods. The focus of the proposed project is on obtaining physical predictions for basic nuclear interactions and properties with controlled uncertainties - arising primarily from extrapolation to the physical quark masses and to the continuum limit - accounted for systematically. Among the nuclear physics questions that this research project is focused on answering are: Which two- and three-baryon systems are bound and what are their binding energies? Are there three-body bound systems involving hyperons? What are the low-energy hyperon-hyperon and hyperon-nucleon phase shifts, and how will knowledge of these quantities help unravel the role of hyperons and hypernuclei in dense matter such as might occur in the core of neutron stars?

This research will help provide a link between long-observed properties of atomic nuclei and the theoretical framework that is believed to provide a basis for these observations, by taking advantages of advances in computing technology and developments in theoretical physics that have only recently made this effort possible. Graduate student training forms an integral part of this project, and will provide education in theoretical physics as well as forefront computing methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nuclei are among the most complex systems that emerge from Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the fundamental theory of the strong interaction. With the advent of high-performance computing it has become possible to simulate nuclear properties and interactions from first principles using lattice QCD, which is a method for solving QCD numerically with big computers.  This method is essential for establishing nuclear physics as a branch of the Standard Model in which quantitative predictions can be made with fully controlled uncertainties. The cost of these simulations is high; for instance, a determination of the binding energy of the alpha particle at the ten-percent level would require years of running on the fastest supercomputers in the world. Despite these severe cost limitations, available resources have allowed a great deal of progress to be made. The main focus of this project has been on providing benchmark calculations of the binding energies of the light nuclei and of simple nuclear reactions. I will describe these results in turn. The first determination of the binding energies of the light nuclei and hypernuclei, up to systems with four baryons, was a part of this project. Due to cost limitations, the simulations were performed at unphysically large values of the light quark masses. As more resources become available, simulations at ever-lighter quark masses can be performed, ultimately allowing for a controlled extrapolation to the physical point where the light-quark masses take their physical values. As a result of this investigation, we now know that almost all of the two-, three- and four-baryon systems that we have chosen to study are bound at heavy light-quark masses, and, importantly, the basic methodology that allows these determinations is now very-well tested. The first nuclear reactions have now been measured using lattice QCD at unphysically-heavy light-quark masses. Lattice QCD simulations are performed in a spacetime volume of finite extent. Therefore, the simulations necessarily measure energy eigenstates of the QCD Hamiltonian in a finite volume. When interested in continuum observables like reaction rates, it is necessary to map the information contained in the lattice QCD measured energy level to the continuum observable of interest. In what is perhaps the most striking result to date for nuclear physics from lattice QCD, the rate for a neutron and a proton combining to give a deuteron and a photon was measured at various light-quark masses and extrapolated to give a result that is consistent with experiment, albeit with large runcertainties.
